events.message: Travis CI system link added for clarity (https://travis-ci.org/)

events.body:
We've switched to our own ci system with config files. They can be executed on any machine. Currently we use Appveyor, Cirrus and Travis for build resources, but I don't think it is worth listing all of them in the top-level readme.

I suggest to strip down the verbosity a bit.

rename.from: Travis CI system link (https://travis-ci.org/) added for clarity
rename.to: CI system link added, clarity increased

events.body: @MarcoFalke @practicalswift could you merge this pr now.

> could you merge this pr now

This is not how contributing works here. Please refer to our docs

"If you have problems with squashing or other git workflows, you can enable "Allow edits from maintainers" in the right-hand sidebar of the GitHub web interface and ask for help in the pull request." - (Sentence in the contribution docs)

@practicalswift I think u can "squash and merge" as I have allowed edits by maintainers.

rename.from: CI system link added, clarity increased
rename.to: doc: CI system link added, clarity increased

events.body: In future, don't open multiple PRs (#20224) for the same change. If you'd like to contribute to this project you'll need to learn how to use git. That includes how to squash, rebase, edit commits messages etc.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -56,7 +56,7 @@ There are also [regression and integration tests](/test), written
 in Python, that are run automatically on the build server.

@@ -56,7 +56,7 @@ There are also [regression and integration tests](/test), written
 in Python, that are run automatically on the build server.
 These tests can be run (if the [test dependencies](/test) are installed) with: `test/functional/test_runner.py`
 
-The Travis CI system makes sure that every pull request is built for Windows, Linux, and macOS, and that unit/sanity tests are run automatically.
+The [Travis CI system](https://travis-ci.org/) makes sure that every pull request is built for Windows, Linux, and macOS, and that unit/sanity tests are run automatically.
comments.body:
```suggestion
The [CI system](/ci) defines build configs for Windows, Linux, and macOS, unit/sanity tests are part of the CI configs.
```
